Given that I want students to learn much as possible, here’s something I’m in two minds about. The course workload is high. So less reading material will help. The course has many prerequisites. So more pre-read material will help. Those are both valid but different directions. What do you all think the students of this course will prefer? Are there ways of breaking the compromise?

It’s hectic for sure! Extensive effort by you/team is very evident. Personally, I’m enjoying the pace, content and the learnings. For the issue raised, I suggest we work on pre-reqs. As I see it, two ways to do this - collaborate internally with other teams to introduce these concepts alongside. For instance, MAD1 can introduce GitHub, devtools; BDM can provide overview about LLMs; programming aspects are already covered at this stage so no change(python/colab. Note# TDS has no pre-requisite and students may not have taken these subjects yet. That brings us to next point TDS focused independent pre-reqs. In this direction, we already have Module 1, Everyday Tools. My suggestion would be to strengthen this - a) categorise the content/videos. A brief on why are we learning these, for which section/purpose, and to what outcome. Today, they are just embedded videos b) Introduce PAs, as in other subjects. Say one dedicated PA on GitHub, another on LLM, and may be one more on devtools (totally based on the coverage required for the subject) Additionally - unlike other courses, this one is very fast-paced and ever-changing. You may want to consider additional staffing, comm efforts, and increased frequency of sessions. To optimise the pace and redistribute some of the load, I suggest we revisit Module 6 (Geo/Network), both on content (misaligned with existing flow of “tools”) and sequence (may be after Module 8?). How about we introduce this as an optional Module? Thank you
Interesting! A few quick questions: What does PA stand for? Assuming that’s an assistant, what do they do in other courses? How often do other courses change content across terms?

PA stands for practice assignment in this context. Regarding the content change, not that much apart from some necessary improvement. GAs(Graded assignments) remains same leading to a possibility of students just using the answers given by previous students, without actually solving them.

First of all, I’d like to thank Prof. Anand and the teaching assistants for this course. This course is industry relevant, immersive, frequently updated and the content is extremely valuable. The projects and the ROE are creative, engaging and interesting. Being unique in each term, a significant amount of preparation and deliberation have gone into creating and publishing the tests. I would suggest not to alter the structure of the course (e.g. not to reduce the content but if possible, make this course a 4 credit course by adding 4 weeks of additional content in the future terms) because by the end of this course, a student will know an assortment of tools to choose from for a given data science problem statement. A few suggestions (please note: they are in response only to Prof. Anand’s note and do not refer to any other note in this thread): From a student’s standpoint: Students who have already completed MLP, BDM, BA, MAD1/2, DBMS courses from the program will find this course relatively simpler. So if it is feasible on a student’s part, one option is to take this course after one has completed some of these courses because they will already have a reasonable grasp on ML libraries, javascript (TypeScript/ReactJS/VueJS/nodejs if I am not mistaken) plus SQL (as part of DBMS course). However, there are students who are just taking the diploma course (and do not neccessarily study MAD1/2, DBMS). In terms of co-requisites, for anyone who is pursuing a diploma in Data Science (and not diploma in programming), having MLP as a co-requisite will help. It will be helpful if number of courses in a term is chosen based on one’s available bandwidth (whether one can spend that many hours/week as indicated in the course description page per course times the number of subjects chosen). Speaking from a personal experience, this is my first term in this program and with 4 courses (2 of them being math courses), I haven’t been able to complete some of the TA sessions in TDS throughout all the weeks in this course, so I believe, unless this point is taken care of by a student (at the beginning of each term), the material (in any course) can get quickly overwhelming only because one does not have enough time to complete all the material published in a particular week, From a course standpoint (please ignore any if they have already been explored or deliberated on before and were deemed infeasible (from an operations standpoint or otherwise)): Please check the feasibility of introducing gamification in couple of foundational modules (say, for example, a sandbox wherein a student can debug through a set of 15-20 html/javascript/css/python - calibrated questions of progressively increasing difficulty). The code can have some deliberate errors, for example. A marginal bonus may be added to the GA score. As a precursor to above, I think a few additional videos on the following topics will be helpful in setting the context for the material that follows: HTML/CSS/Javascript and Python debugging foundations (debugging using a visual debugger

errors, for example. A marginal bonus may be added to the GA score. As a precursor to above, I think a few additional videos on the following topics will be helpful in setting the context for the material that follows: HTML/CSS/Javascript and Python debugging foundations (debugging using a visual debugger as opposed to log statements) Tools to view data in transit in a data transformation pipeline (for instance, additional coverage on tools such as Data Wrangler) Concept of an API - essentials of an API, how to debug GET/POST requests using a visual software such as Postman will help someone who is familiar with Python (assuming everyone in this course is) but is not familiar (yet) with the concepts of an API. Please check the feasibility of introducing a TDS Wiki page (say, on Github) with curated, byte sized tips and tricks (the key here is bite sized nuggets of information, all collated in one location for ease of reference - one inclusion criteria, let’s say something that could be read and understood in under 5 minutes by most - highly useful, yet simple techniques, with snippets of code inline, for example “how to show progress bar for a for loop in python using tqdm() as demonstrated in one of the course videos”). Topics in the Wiki could include (among others): General debugging techniques (Web technologies (JS/html/css) or Python - for example, in a format similar to dev-tips ) Data wrangling techniques - how to think of interesting ways of transforming data (say, why and how one combines dataframes to get to the data needed to solve a problem - techniques (through examples) on how does one break down a data related problems into sub-problems, what’s the thoughprocess involved in such operations, what is the standard approach of debugging etc.) Prompt engineering techniques (for example, what are some of the creative ways of using LLM as a coding, debugging, automation and creative assistance) VS Code tips and tricks (examples, multi cursor editing, how to create snippets of code for reuse, how to use AI completion, Codeium for example) Pull requests can be invited and, as an option, a marginal bonus awarded for contributions. The TA sessions that I have watched so far covers lot of concepts and are well presented - please verify if it is possible to condense the sessions on web scraping (html, cookies, xml, for example) which are more than 2 hours long into condensed videos (say, in the 20-30 minutes timeframe). Please verify if concept of Teams will work in the context of the course. Since the data science program is (almost) entirely online, one of the challenges a section of students face is having a quick, face to face conversation with an expert (at a mutually agreed upon time) when they have something blocking their progress (this is in sharp contrast to an offline program or working in the industry). The teaching assistants in this course have helped immensely in terms of answering questions and conducting TA sessions where they have answered specific questions students have. I

upon time) when they have something blocking their progress (this is in sharp contrast to an offline program or working in the industry). The teaching assistants in this course have helped immensely in terms of answering questions and conducting TA sessions where they have answered specific questions students have. I think, this concept may be extended by forming teams say a group of 2-3 students (with varying experience levels - one of them preferably with industry experience) who group together (over a call for a predefined interval of time) periodically (say, a few times in a month) and have a one on one conversations on anything that is blocking their progress (in terms of prerequisites one should know) or just general guidance. Having said so, the biggest downside that I see of institutionalizing teams is that such a channel may quickly degrade to a channel that is leveraged only to finish assignments and projects by exchanging code (without necessarily spending time in understanding the code and the related concepts) - that defeats the whole purpose of using a channel to only receive general guidance. Concept of Teams may work where a significant portion (say 80% or more of the overall score) is proctored. With 70% of this course’s score being unproctored, I think a concept that works so well in the industry (the mentor concept), will quickly deteriorate to being a mechanism to just score more marks. However, I am listing the concept anyways.

Thanks for sharing PYQs. [Assuming one already has a reasonable grasp on the functionality offered by standard scraping libraries (including being able to code for it in Python) for converting various input formats to, lets say, a Pandas dataframe] It will be interesting to see if scraping code can be generated using state of the art LLMs e.g. say given an array of input formats (for example, html, xml, pdf, parquet, database, image etc.), is it possible to generate the scraping code using an LLM providing some prompts to parse through the required information from the files and transform into a standard Pandas dataframe (which can then be used for data analysis). Just wanted to check if anyone has explored this use case and has marginal or satisfactory success with the same (measured with respect to the time it takes between manual code (assuming one thoroughly understand the standard scraping libraries but still has to custom write some code for the unique schema/ask for a particular use case) versus prompting/iterating/testing through the LLM generated code)? Thanks.

So will such clarifications be addressed via: Case 1: the discourse thread for the ROE (assuming there will be one thread for the ROE), or Case 2: One can assume if the answer one has calculated and inputted in the textbox and verifies through the “Check” button - if that says, it is correct (for example, NAs and ‘nan’ are answers in the answerset shared for this PYQ), then that is, in fact, the final answer. Please review and advise. Question 5 NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA Philip Morris Products S.A. NA NA NA NA NA SOCIETE DES PRODUITS NESTLE S.A. NA

Yes. We are doing this at Straive by passing the HTML for thousands of obituary sites and having GPT 4o Mini identify the selectors to extract the deceased’s details. That’s one among a few other exercises but this one is in production. For an individual it would take about 3 hours per site. LLMs reduce this to zero at about 80% accuracy.

Thank you Prof. Anand for sharing this use case. LLMs achieving an 80% accuracy in extracting a person’s data from thousands of obituary websites is impressive. Since an individual’s information on a webpage can be highly nuanced, unstructured and scattered, are there any benchmarks available of GPT-4o having outperformed GPT 4o Mini in this particular use case (in terms of GPT-4o’s advanced understanding of the nuances of natural language and (presumably) the underlying website structure too - just curious to know if the best model translates in any real, tangible gains in terms of increasing the accuracy - say a 5% (or higher gain).

For example, if value A should have been mapped to field B, it has been mapped to field C instead. Please explore other edge cases including possibility of multiple pieces of data being merged to a single field in the generated json where ideally (a manual review should tell) it should have been mapped to multiple fields in the json instead. Although it is possible to eyeball through the entire dataset (which is just around 20 records) manually in a few minutes and verify if any of the cases above is true, you may want to run the input data through two LLMs (say, chatgpt versus Claude Sonnet (or any other)) and then do a diff compare on the two generate json files (say, using a diff utility in VS Code) to see if there is any minor diff that it shows (although like I said, since the dataset is so small, a cross LLM comparison is just an overkill for this particular scenario - you can try this as an option only if you’re running short of time because part of the objective of this question and the next question is being able to spot where the AI went wrong in the first question, feed in all the findings/errors/ommisions to the AI so the AI generates a (near) error free json in the next question).

Yes, I think it depends from one data set to another. In the first iteration, in my dataset, the AI (ChatGpt4-o mini) errored in merging two pieces of data into one field Role: “Engineer at Tech Dynamics” whereas it really should have splitted this into two fields Role: “Engineer” and org: “Tech Dynamics”. It’s near impossible to know beforehand whether AI will (or will not) error out on any nuances. In other words, it is near impossible to feed in the ‘perfect’ prompts on the get go. After a manual review and sharing those feedback to the AI on where it messed up in the first question, it gets (way) better in the second iteration (as far as I recall, I did not make any changes to the json in the second question and the validator outputted the correct code in the first try).

should we just convert the given 20 attendees to vcard format as per schema or the prompt should also populate any missing data for those entries?

Just convert them into vcard format. Don’t populate any missing data, leave them blank, i.e. `""` empty string. You don’t have to get keys with empty values because the validator removes empty values anyway. For ex: `{ "fn": "Ashley Walker", "bday": "1980-08-05", "email": "", "tel": "", "adr": { "country-name": "Australia" }, "org": "", "title": "Designer", "photo": "", "url": "", "nickname": "Ash" }` and `{ "fn": "Ashley Walker", "bday": "1980-08-05", "adr": { "country-name": "Australia" }, "title": "Designer", "nickname": "Ash" }` both work fine.

Mathematically correlation function is defined in two arrays of numbers, if we don’t have them (due to incorrect data) answer should be undefined not between [-1,1]

The data is wrong not because you obtained the wrong dataset, but because it has been a) improperly extracted, b) improperly formated, c) improperly updated, d) cached improperly (not doing a browser hard refresh and its using the old submission) Therefore, if the above was done, it is guaranteed that the script WILL work correctly. In other words, if your dataset is wrong, its because of human error. The goals of this exercise is to understand the responsibility of extracting, cleaning, transforming, and producing the right results. Any failure in the early part of the chain will lead to erroneous results at the end. So saying that its “not my fault that my results are wrong because i have the wrong dataset,” is not understanding your responsibility to the first stages of the process. image 1691×407 49.8 KB Hi Could you shed some light on PROCESS of analysis please? Specifically, where should we display it so that the peers could review it? In the README.md file or in the optional code file? What should be its format? Also regarding RESULTS of analysis, is the 2nd bullet point in the REDAME.md file to be considered as the result? Regards

Hi Nomaan, Peers will focus on the 3 bullet points. An explanation of how you scraped the data The most interesting and surprising fact you found after analyzing the the data An actionable recommendation for developers based on your analysis Everything you provide as support for the 3 bullet points is upto the peers whether to consider in their evaluation. The bullet points will be in the README.md The process is about how you scraped, how you obtained the result and how did you formulate the recommendation. (So in effect it involves all 3 bullet points) The results are a combination of the facts and your recommendation. Sometimes a fact might lead to an erroneous recommendation due to mistakes in process. So results cannot be considered in isolation of point 2 or point 3. Its an amalgam of the two (at least that is my understanding). In other words there is not a clear distinction. The three bullet points will be evaluated wholistically to answer the questions of ranking PROCESS and RESULTS. Hope that helped. Nice that you are thinking about this carefully Most people just do the analytical part and forget the most important bit: communicating something useful. Kind regards,
Hi , Thank you for your kind response What you said has definitely given me some clarity regarding the approach. Will keep that in mind. Appreciate the guidance Kind Regards

Which tool are you using? I used sklearn’s LinearRegression model to find out the regression slope. Couple of points you can check are, You are counting words of the Bio by splitting it on whitespaces and not finding the length of the Bio. You are not considering the rows where Bio does not exist, just get rid of them from the calculation.

I used both model sklearn.linear_model as well as satatsmodels.formula.api. In both models i am getting same answer, when i update and check answer, it says incorrect. i did word counting by bio splitting and had also eliminated all the rows which has no value.

Sometimes students have done an incorrect split on a single whitespace. That WILL give you the wrong answer. Eg. `This is a bio. This is a bio.` If you spilt on a single whitespace you will get 5 for the first one and 4 for the second one. Even though both should have resulted in 4 being the word count. This is a VERY common mistake. You have to treat all whitespace as a delimiter not individually. Kind regards

Here’s the thing. Once you have the code in place and have received the API response in CSV format, you upload those CSVs to GitHub and start answering the questions. When you reach questions 11, 12, 13, and 15, you start wondering where things are going wrong. After reviewing all the hints, I realized that the code checking your answer treats “true” and “false” as strings. If you check the file uploaded on GitHub and look at the raw version, you’ll see that it has everything stored as either TRUE/FALSE or True/False. Opening the file on your machine doesn’t help, because Excel automatically interprets these values as booleans. Here’s what I did—not the best method, and I’m sure someone could code a solution, but I did the best I could. I copied the raw file content from GitHub and pasted it into a Word document. I replaced all instances of FALSE with false and TRUE with true, then copied that back into the GitHub raw file and committed the changes. Once done, return to the project page and enter the same answers you initially got through your code or manual calculations, and you’ll see things align. I know this isn’t the most elegant solution, and I should handle it programmatically, but sometimes you have to implement fixes that work rather than seeking the most elegant solution. Hope this helps!

while i was trying to call the github api to scrape users data, after fetching some data my script stopped. It was returning a 429 status code. I was sure the no of users in Mumbai are not that low, so after some investigation and asking chatgpt about it I understand there is a rate limit set by github to avoid overburdening their servers. One solution to this is creating a personal access token which increases your rate limit from ~60 to ~5000 per hour. But i have checked and there are around ~55,000 users (in Mumbai). Are we supposed to fetch 5000 records per hour for 11 hours; which does not seem like the way to go, or is there some other way to handle this rate limit. Please advice.

You’re right, the unauthenticated rate limits are 60/hr and authenticated are 5,000/hr Project 1 is carefully designed to stay within the rate limits. In other words, if you use the GitHub API effectively, you’ll be able to get the data you need within 60 requests . Part of the exercise is figuring out how to use the GitHub API so as to get the maximum information with the fewest requests. Happy learning!

Minor suggestion: Anytime we click on a youtube video link (from the course dashboard or the github landing page), we essentially loose the parent page and need to navigate back to the parent page by pressing the browser’s back button. Parent page (e.g. the week’s summary page) contains the context/flow of topics for the entire week and I think there is a need for it to stay intact. Can we instead launch the video(s) in separate window(s) so we do not loose the “parent” page? Thanks.
Exactly, I was thinking the same. The videos could’ve been embed instead.

A good point. I have thought about it. The web design best practice is to open links in the same tab because: Users can control it : Users can right-click and “Open link in new tab”. But if the link is set to open in a new tab, there’s no way around that. Also, users expect clicking to continue in the same window by default. Browser Behavior and Navigation : Most modern browsers preserve the page scroll location when you press the back button. Also, new windows can disrupt the flow of the back button and make navigation less intuitive. Accessibility : Screen readers don’t do so well with new windows. It may not be immediately apparent that a new window has opened, leading to confusion. A good workaround for these is TamperMonkey . You can write your own scripts that automatically load video links from TDS in a new window.

Dear Anju, I have checked both questions, and I am getting the answer that is within the provided range. GA3 is challenging. If I may be completely candid, it looks like an answer spat out by GPT. For example there is a meaningless operation `match = pattern.match (line)` Why? what’s wrong with just `line` ? (assuming logs are an array of lines) Did you try to examine the output of a few samples of each match to see if you are actually getting the expected output at each stage of the regex? It might be that your regex is not performing as expected and filtering out the wrong lines. Regex is a tough and unforgiving tool to debug. I will show how to solve this in the live TA session, and I will show a much simpler method that is humanly easily verifiable. From the movie Maverick Topgun… The end is inevitable, Maverick. Your kind is headed for extinction. jjaevdoscwpb1 2034×1203 322 KB Someday GPT will relegate such skills obsolete… But until that day… Yours truly, TDS TA PS: Moral of the story is its okay to use GPT. In fact we encourage it (it is the future), but please try to do some basic debugging and checks first. Use GPT in a progressive step wise fashion so that you can verifiably solve the problem. I am here to guide you on your TDS journey. I will not be able to debug GPT’s code all the time because, lets face it. GPT knows a lot more than me. It just does not have “brains”. So sometimes you need to think about what is actually happening instead of completely treating it as a magic black box. Cheers!

The web archive website has been hacked and therefore we are not able to check it. However, I can safely say that usually if the page has Javascript enabled you will get one extra item and without you will get one less. (I made the same mistake when solving this GA). Turning off the Javascript (just for this page) usually fixes the problem. (Note: I have not checked your actual script due to the page outage - but the symptoms of the two different answers are usually what makes the difference). Kind regards,

Hi used a script to exclude items from styling and JavaScript. In cases where there are additional items (only if they exist in JavaScript), they won’t affect the final output. However, strange thing to note: the same script is giving different results when run in the console versus in Colab. The question now is: which result should be consider correct?

Typically, the on page console tools will be more accurate as it is able to retrieve correctly the complete dom straight from the browser. Beautiful soup although very good, can sometimes run into some limitations because certain scripts are not triggerred correctly when retrived by an agent other than a browser. Thats why its good to learn both methods.

But the same script is giving different results. In the console, the answer is 193, while using BeautifulSoup, the answer is 192. Now, among the options available on the portal for this question, 193 is not one of them.
If you disable Javascript from the devtools you will get 192. It would be instructive to find out why by comparing the two arrays. Kind regards

Try this: `$$('.ipc-metadata-list-summary-item').map(item => [ item.querySelector('.ipc-title__text').textContent, item.querySelector('.sc-8f57e62c-1:nth-child(1)').querySelector('span:last-child').textContent, item.querySelector('.sc-8f57e62c-1:nth-child(2)').querySelector('span:last-child').textContent, item.querySelector('.sc-8f57e62c-1:nth-child(3)').querySelector('span:last-child').textContent, item.querySelector('.ipc-rating-star--rating').textContent, item.querySelector('.ipc-rating-star--voteCount').textContent.trim(), ]);` Note: The CSS pseudo-class selector, selects the n-th child of a parent element. In this example, I `sc-8f57e62c-1` is the class of the `li` element.
Now, It is right. I haven’t given the parent element for nth child, this works well with/without giving the span as last child. Thanks!

Hi Tarika, You have not changed the user_agent. If you read the documentation carefully, it would have been mentioned about the need to change the user_agent. The first clue comes from the HTTP response code. 403 Have a look to see what that means, MDN Web Docs HTTP response status codes - HTTP | MDN HTTP response status codes indicate whether a specific HTTP request has been successfully completed. Responses are grouped in five classes: Try and change the user_agent to something that is personalised to your application and give it a try. Kind regards

Here is an OPTIONAL project: Record a 10-minute video in which you create an application entirely using LLMs and deploy it. Any app is fine . Any language. Simple or complex. Business or gaming. Anything is fine. Your choice. Create the app only using LLMs . You can use an LLM (ChatGPT, Claude.ai, Gemini, Cursor, Cody, etc.) but you can only prompt the app to write code. You can copy-paste code and run code don’t write or edit even a single line of code directly. Use LLMs to debug and edit. Code completion is NOT allowed – only prompting/chatting. Record the entire process in 10 min . Don’t edit, trim, enhance, or annotate the video. You should record yourself creating the entire app from start to finish. Practice beforehand if you like. Record in 1 take. Share the video and app . Publish the video publicly anywhere (e.g. YouTube and share the link.) Publish the app publicly anywhere (e.g. GitHub pages, Glitch.me , Heroku, etc.) or upload a ZIP file with the code (for slightly lower marks.) Submit via a reply to this thread. Multiple submissions per person are fine. Work in groups if you like but only the submitter gets marks. I will award up to 1 bonus mark at my discretion based on: How well you prompt the LLM How impressive the app is (if you’ve hosted it - I probably won’t run your code) How closely you followed the rules above This exercise is to help you (and me) learn a topic that’ll probably change the way we all code: using LLMs to code. Cutoff date: 7 Oct 2024, AoE

The quiz id is ad9dbe7c55414265a919ef4bf3629cce. `find . -type f -size +6418c -newermt '2024-04-23 06:03:00' -exec du -b {} + | awk '{total += $1} END {print "Total size in bytes:", total}'` This is the command I ran for Q4

Typically disk usage which is in blocks rather than bytes is different from how many bytes a file is. A 3 byte file might still take 4KB on disk if the smallest disk block size is 4KB (default on NT) You are getting the disk usage space which varies from computer to computer rather than answering the exact question that was asked. Kind regards

A simpler solution is to simply use the ls -l command and send the output to a file, which can then be easily processed. Of course you could use a bash script as well. But if you are not proficient in bash, it would very hard to diagnose what is wrong. Why wield a samurai sword which requires great skill and experience to slice bread, when you can just do it with your kitchen bread knife instead? Kind regards

My quiz id is: a0a94e41cda5468ab68ef27645fe3b69 I’m getting an incorrect answer although it’s accessible and correct. error 1600×459 104 KB This is the link for reference: https://raw.githubusercontent.com/anshulbaliga7/tds-iitm/main/index.html and https://anshulbaliga7.github.io/tds-iitm/ .anand , please could you look into this. Thank You.

Fascinating! https://anshulbaliga7.github.io/tds-iitm/index.html is UTF-16 encoded text that’s being served as UTF-8. Browsers handle the conversion automatically, but code does not. – please re-encode as UTF-8 or plain ASCII. And welcome to the complications of character encoding. For more details, there’s a great video by Scott Hanselman is a great introduction.
Worked! Thank you sir!
Sir, could you please tell what clue led you to catch this discrepancy? Because if we look, it all looks same to us on the browser whether its UTF-16 or UTF-8.

It looked the same to me, too. So I cloned the repo (I think – I might have run `curl` on the URL) and piped it through `od -ha` which gives an octal dump. That’s where I spotted a bunch of weird characters. You could also clone it and open it in an editor like VS Code. You’ll see the encoding at the bottom-right.

– yes, that can happen. This is a good opportunity to talk about two-way doors. Jeff Bezos wrote : `Some decisions are consequential and irreversible or nearly irreversible – one-way doors – and these decisions must be made methodically, carefully, slowly, with great deliberation and consultation. If you walk through and don’t like what you see on the other side, you can’t get back to where you were before. We can call these Type 1 decisions. But most decisions aren’t like that – they are changeable, reversible – they’re two-way doors. If you’ve made a suboptimal Type 2 decision, you don’t have to live with the consequences for that long. You can reopen the door and go back through. Type 2 decisions can and should be made quickly by high judgment individuals or small groupsAs organizations get larger, there seems to be a tendency to use the heavy-weight Type 1 decision-making process on most decisions, including many Type 2 decisions. The end result of this is slowness, unthoughtful risk aversion, failure to experiment sufficiently, and consequently diminished invention. We’ll have to figure out how to fight that tendency` GA1 is a good example of a 2-way door. Try an approach. If the answer is incorrect, try another. You get instant feedback. No need to check. Here’s what I suggest. Go ahead and let the newer file replace the older one. If the answer’s incorrect, try it the other way around. One or the other will work if you have the rest of the steps right. But to your question, yes, duplicate files CAN occur.

I faced the same scenario where I had two files with same name, but case sensitive as ‘u.txt’ and ‘U.txt’ in the same folder. In windows and WSL I was forced to keep either one. Then I had to upload the file to my google drive, mounted it on Colab and used the tried it on Colab Terminal. The terminal on Colab was using a different file system and it was accepting same names with case sensitivity. image 738×690 25.3 KB you can see ‘u.txt’ and ‘U.txt’ The same steps and commands on WSL was giving me wrong SHA key. But when I used the same steps on Colab Terminal, it worked.

Windows files system is case insensitive. Linux typically uses a case sensitive filesystem (although you can configure it to whatever you wanted). Typically a VM is completely isolated, however because WSL still has to be accessible to the windows filesystem (you can for example view the WSL filesystem directly from windows file explorer), it seems to have been configured with a case insensitive filesystem. This is odd in your case because Windows documentation seems to suggest the default is otherwise. Case Sensitivity | Microsoft Learn Google Colab notebooks has a linux backend and currently runs on Ubuntu 22.04 You can run these in your google colab to see what it runs `!cat /etc/*release` This is the file system info `!df -Th` Incredibly on ext4 (which typically what most default linux systems use), you are even able to enable case insensitivity on a directory by directory basis! (for those power users that have very specific use cases). Windows also claims to now support this feature on NT through the use of directory flags. Nice bit of work. Kind regards

Hi Hari, Please refer to the course introduction page. Most students ignore this page, but for TDS it is a source of very valuable information. `You should be comfortable coding in Python, HTML, JavaScript, Excel, and have a basic understanding of data science concepts.` GA0 is meant to point you to the problem (skill requirements). We will provide some more specific resources as the course progresses, but for the above, any google search will provide you good beginner resources to get started. One of the key skills of Data Science is given a problem, finding the data. How you solve that problem is part of your growth. Since these are very basic requirements, we do not typically give recommendations as everyone has a different learning style. You have to find resources that suit your style. For the more in depth topics we will cover them in the live sessions, lectures and the resource links we will provide that go with those topics. Please feel free to contribute what you have discovered to be great resources (as new ones keep popping up and they are quite good, so it will be good for all of us including the TDS team, to see what students find). Last term for example did a phenomenal job of collating information of the various resources for TDS. TDS May 2024 Portal Resource Links Tools in Data Science `Here is the collection of all the links provided on the portal up to the current week for the May 2024 term for learning TDS. I felt the need to save all of them for my learning checklist and future reference. I’m sharing this in the hope that it might save you some time if you also need the links in one place. I plan to update this post regularly with week-wise content. WEEK1 Data discoveryhttps://datasetsearch.research.google.com/https://data.gov/https://data.gov.ru/?language=en…` Please note that each term TDS changes. So not everything from last term will be the same. So not everything on that discourse post will be used. It is a good starting point. Kind regards

Here is a summary of Week 1 TA session, in order to save you time from watching 2 hours of ASMR. For those that want fat free info: TDS is practical. READ the Course Introduction LOTs of invaluable Information. Start preparing for ROE NOW. End term is theory based and is much easier than GAs, Projects, ROE. Project Score = 80% based on answers to project questions + 20% are from Peer Reviews. Project comprises of Quantitative and Qualitative. Peer reviews are on the qualitative part. Reviews that are outliers are rejected. Bonus Marks are only on Discourse. Answers must be submitted according to the Discourse post. Discretion of Bonus Marks are upto how impressed the Prof is with your submission. Bonus Marks are really worth it. In total they are worth half of the total GAs. Also Bonus Marks are great fun! ROE Mocks are just previous ROEs. There is no pattern for ROEs. They are never the same as previous ROEs. However core skills of ROEs remain the same: Scraping webpages. HTML, CSS, Javascript (particularly for selecting dom elements), sessions, cookies. Scrapping PDFs. Python Tabula library. Python (especially Pandas) Nominatim SQL and maybe some other minor tools. ROE week content: Week 2 to 4 ROE is open book (not proctored, use anything you wish including GPT) ROE is very, very hard. Start preparing now. SCT is NOT required for ROE. Week 5: you will get some $ allowance for LLM tokens. Awesome. And super fun topic. Optional Videos in week 2 are NOT optional. They are a necessary for ROE (and end term). Bonus 1: Making LLM app: Just sharing the code on Github is not an app. `Github` and `Github Pages` are NOT the same thing. Github Pages is a web server where you can deploy your app. Github repo is just a place to store and share your code. An app is a working application that anyone with web access can use just by clicking on the link you provide. Your app has to be submitted in the Discourse post where the Bonus post was made. Subscribe to Discourse emails for TDS. That way you will not miss important information like the Bonus questions. Listen to Podcast - very informational about current data science industry. BASH - there is a great book for this from System Commands. accounts.google.com Google Drive: Sign-in Access Google Drive with a Google account (for personal use) or Google Workspace account (for business use). The links at the bottom and top of videos in the modules are very valuable. Week 1 Video session is available on the TDS You Tube Video Playlist. Access will NOT be given to the video links in the calendar. The ONLY place to get access to the videos will be the TDS You Tube Video Channel . Kind regards, TDS TA
be the TDS You Tube Video Channel . Kind regards, TDS TA

The answers vanish and the test refreshes when you close and come back to the test. The act of closing and coming back later is equivalent to a refresh is my understanding but someone can correct if I am wrong.

One of the expectations of GA1 is that students complete it in one sitting. Therefore even if you submit, and come back to it, it will get refreshed. If you have programmatically solved the question (as is the intent most of the time, because its faster, scalable, repeatable), then resolving a new set should be trivial. If you do a lot of manual solving, then yes it will be very tedious and you have not gained the learning that is expected. Bottom line: Do the GA1 in one go. This feature is being tested only for the GA1 (and GA0). The remaining GAs will be normal like you are used to in the seek portal. For next term the goal is to roll this out for most if not all the GAs (in TDS at least) by learning what to improve and what achieves the best learning outcome. Regards

image 708×575 49.5 KB This is the output before modification. image 708×575 47.3 KB This is the output of grep after all the modification My hash value is still wrong, I am not sure as to why. I manually tried copying the files. Quiz ID 0051445841f841b8a4f266cdc9918ffe Please help .anand

Short answer: Please run `grep . * | LC_ALL=C sort | sha256sum` and it’ll work. Long answer: Ah, but is the second list really sorted? Should `dHD` BEFORE `GCtPC0` ? Is small `d` before capital `G` ? It depends on how the UNIX sort command operates. If the locale (e.g. via the environment variable `LC_ALL` ) is set to `C` , it sorts like programmers expect — uppercase before lowercase. If it’s set to something else, e.g. `en_GB.UTF` , it would sort like the British do. I missed anticipating that others’ systems would have different locale settings. Now, I’ve changed the question now to explicitly set `LC_ALL=C` to get consistent sorting. Thanks for flagging this!

When extracting files from a ZIP archive using Windows’ built-in “Extract All” feature, you may notice that all extracted files have the same modification date. This is default behavior in Windows and can cause issues if you need accurate file dates. To preserve the original file modification dates: Use the `unzip` command instead of Windows’ extraction tool. In Visual Studio Code, open a terminal as Git Bash, which provides access to the `unzip` command. Run the `unzip` command to extract the files which will maintain their original timestamps. – yes, you may want to rethink. With a strong HTML/JS foundation, you’ll score more. Else, you’ll need to work harder, but you’ll learn more. What would you prefer?

Hi Viraj, The reason for GA0 is simple. It gives you a flavour of what you need to be comfortable with in order to be able to do well in the course. Generally if you are struggling with these basics (because that is what they are), then you will have to put extra effort in order to get up to speed. TDS covers a lot of ground in terms of the tools used for Data Science. Past experience shows us that students who are not comfortable with the basics find the Remote Online Exam very challenging and many score 0. So the GA0 gives you a chance to assess if you want to “bite the bullet” and take the course or do you want to give yourself some time to become familiar with the basic requirements. We do this early so that you can still avail the drop window, if you find the the course challenging. We (the TDS team) have lobbied hard to actually have some concrete (programming) pre-requisites for this course, but the BS management (not the TDS team) has countered with, this is not possible because some students only do the Data Science Diploma. I totally agree that these requirements must be made known prior to taking this course. However due to an impasse on how to structure the diploma, to better deal with this issue, it is what it is. I know this is not of much comfort. Having said that, you also have one of the best professors and I dare say with the backing of data (some of the best TAs) in the program who are here to help you succeed. But it will require much effort compared to most other subjects. Students who have been through TDS can mostly vouch for one thing. Its one of the most interesting, practical and useful course in making you job ready. But it is a trial by fire. However if you have done the diploma in programming, its fairly easy (which is why we always recommend taking it towards the end of the diploma). Hope that helps. Kind regards

Hi Viraj, The reason for GA0 is simple. It gives you a flavour of what you need to be comfortable with in order to be able to do well in the course. Generally if you are struggling with these basics (because that is what they are), then you will have to put extra effort in order to get up to speed. TDS covers a lot of ground in terms of the tools used for Data Science. Past experience shows us that students who are not comfortable with the basics find the Remote Online Exam very challenging and many score 0. So the GA0 gives you a chance to assess if you want to “bite the bullet” and take the course or do you want to give yourself some time to become familiar with the basic requirements. We do this early so that you can still avail the drop window, if you find the the course challenging. We (the TDS team) have lobbied hard to actually have some concrete (programming) pre-requisites for this course, but the BS management (not the TDS team) has countered with, this is not possible because some students only do the Data Science Diploma. I totally agree that these requirements must be made known prior to taking this course. However due to an impasse on how to structure the diploma, to better deal with this issue, it is what it is. I know this is not of much comfort. Having said that, you also have one of the best professors and I dare say with the backing of data (some of the best TAs) in the program who are here to help you succeed. But it will require much effort compared to most other subjects. Students who have been through TDS can mostly vouch for one thing. Its one of the most interesting, practical and useful course in making you job ready. But it is a trial by fire. However if you have done the diploma in programming, its fairly easy (which is why we always recommend taking it towards the end of the diploma). Hope that helps. Kind regards

, As many students mentioned, end term exam was easier than expected I have one question to review from the end term for potentially alternative options. In which of the following domains is network analysis commonly applied? for this question, " Social Media and Genetic Research are the most common domains for network analysis. Climate Modeling is less typical but might still have some niche applications." the question is “Commonly applied” which has stumped me, and first natural one is “Social Media like LinkedIn” was most commonly used. Not sure Climate modeling was commonly used application of network analysis. Ask to you : I would like you to consider most commonly used options of “Social Media”, and “Genetic Research” along with “All of the above” Could you pl. review this and respond?

Network analysis is used in climate modeling to study complex interactions and relationships within the climate system. It allows researchers to understand how different components of the climate system (e.g., temperature, precipitation, atmospheric circulation) are interconnected. Here are some ways network analysis is applied in climate modeling: Spatio-temporal network analysis for studying climate patterns | Climate Dynamics (2014) ENSO in CMIP5 simulations: network connectivity from the recent past to the twenty-third century | Climate Dynamics (2014) Climate Networks: Climate data (such as temperature or pressure) from different geographical locations can be represented as a network. In this network, nodes represent locations, and edges represent correlations or interactions between climate variables at these locations. This approach helps in identifying key regions that influence global climate patterns. Networks of climate change: connecting causes and consequences | Applied Network Science | Full Text Teleconnections: Network analysis is used to study teleconnections, which are long-distance relationships between climate variables (like the El Niño Southern Oscillation or the North Atlantic Oscillation). By analyzing these networks, researchers can detect how changes in one part of the world affect other regions. Extreme Event Prediction: Networks help in identifying how extreme weather events, like heat waves or storms, propagate through the system. By mapping these events in a network, it becomes easier to predict areas at risk or potential future events based on past occurrences. Climate network analysis helps pinpoint regions at higher risk of extreme weather | ScienceDaily Feedback Loops: Network analysis is useful for identifying feedback loops in the climate system, where changes in one variable influence another, which in turn feeds back into the original variable. For example, melting ice reduces the Earth’s albedo, leading to more warming, which further accelerates ice melt. etc. etc. etc. If you still feel Climate modeling is a “niche” application of network analysis, you can ask the instructors for second consideration. Kind regards

Scatter plots need 2 variables. How will you use a scatter plot to identify outliers in one variable?
Can I get AN answer keys link too please?
Can we visualize outliers in scatter plot Tools in Data Science ``

Scatter plot shows relationship between 2 variables. Its used to visualize correlation. Box plot shows outliers. To identify outliers, you need IQR as well, which box plot depicts. Agreed, but can the scatter plot help you visually identify outliers in a dataset - yes or no

Scatter plots need 2 variables. How will you use a scatter plot to identify outliers in one variable? Agreed, but i the question it is not mentioned if it is one variable or more than one variable. can the scatter plot help you visually identify outliers in a dataset - yes or no

You cannot identify outliers with precision in a scatter plot as you need the IQR or something similar for that, which a scatter plot doesn’t provide. It will only be a visual approximation, which would be more useful as an EDA exercise.

Scatter plots are often used in the real world for bivariate outlier detection through the use of z scores, residuals in regression analysis, elliptic envelope (multivariate normal distribution). All these are precise mathematical tools that can be visually mapped on the scatter plot to detect outliers. Resolution : Q444 will be given marks for both box plots as well as scatter plots being marked as the correct answer.

Hello Regarding the question on the use of bar charts, I (and a lot of other people creating business presentations) have extensively used bar charts to compare two or more variables. For e.g., comparing the revenue of this year vs last year, broken down by quarter. Same for profits, margins, no. of people in the organization and stuff like that. image 1080×363 85.6 KB Kindly share your views.

I have been told by instructors and academics who are much more qualified than me that the improper use of graphs is rife in business presentations and that includes using bar charts for comparing two or more variables. The improper use of charts does not mean that they are the appropriate tool for the job. Hence for this question the correct answer is categorical data. People in the statistics department (and the business department) take particular umbrage to the improper use of graphs. It’s one of their pet peeves. A good analogy is that we can use a spanner to hit a nail. Does not mean its the best tool to hit a nail. In this question it does use the qualifier best and its hard to argue for other choices when categorical data is one of the choices, because that is in fact the best use of a bar chart.

If 95% of the people are using this approach, perhaps it is time for the statisticians and academicians to update their approach and align themselves with the ground reality (aka real world) . Also FYI, there isn’t a single person in any business department who doesn’t use bar charts according to the way I have described. In fact, one would be hard pressed to find other ways in which bar charts are used as a % of usage. You can ask .anand about this if you want. I’m sure he has come across many presentations which use bar charts in his career.

Hi , Can you pls share how the score for project 1 has been calculated? If we consider the 80:20 ratio for submission and peer grading, the marks displayed on the dashboard is different. Also there was a mention of 1 bonus mark for every peer review which is not an outlier . Will we get it ?
One bonus mark from the 100 marks assigned for the peer review, i.e., if peer reviews have 4 marks overall, you get 1% of those 4 marks, which would be 4/100 = 0.04 marks.
Oh ok … …in that case it is of no use …
Do u know how did they calculate the project 1 score ?

From the course introduction page: image 893×433 23 KB Apart from this, I believe each question in Project 1 had an equal number of marks. For e.g., if you have 10 questions and a total of 16 marks (4 additional for peer reviews), then each correct answer should get you 1.6 marks. Multiply the project answer marks by 5 to get your total out of 100. If you want to add peer review marks to it, multiply the marks from the answers by 4 and divide the marks from the peer reviews by 5 and add both of them to get your total marks from Project 1 out of 100.

Hey Everyone, Created this post so that everyone can post their experience of TDS. Will be useful for the future candidates of TDS. Please do share your experiences on how TDS felt to you in week 1 and how it shaped your data science learning curve. Tagging some people to start with. (Your Contribution to TDS is amazing) Please share your experience and tag someone who could. Regards.

Thank you for acknowledging my contribution, however small it may have been. I hope to be even more beneficial to the data science community in the future. My journey with TDS began with great hope, inspired by its name, “Tools in Data Science,” and the practical course outline. The first spark I felt was during the live data scraping sessions by Amit Sir, which were incredibly engaging and fun. “Gramener” and .anand Sir have an indescribable aura that instills hope to achieve the depth Anand Sir has reached in the industry. The very humble and supportive CREATIVE trio of Anand Sir, Sir, and Sir guided us throughout. Whether it was the ROE (which makes me wish for it in place of oppe exams) or the Mission Mars 1-mark optional projects, it was more than I could have asked for when registering for the TDS course. One thing I feel I missed to fully experience the essence of TDS was the weekly Wednesday sessions by Dibu John Sir, as I only watched the recorded sessions on YouTube. When certain modules towards the end of the course had previous term recordings where Dibu Sir interacted with students, I felt I missed something valuable. All the course content provided significant value, thanks to the TDS team . Not just the official team, but the student community in TDS this term was also a delight, especially the efforts of in supporting us through the difficulties we faced.
Regarding the end-term exam, I believe our GPT model needs further training to truly capture the essence and beauty of the subject and question design.

Thank you for tagging me. My overall experience was kind of nice. Initially, Week 1 felt very easy but as the weeks progressed, I felt there were so many tools to learn and handle data differently. This is one of the courses where I didn’t make any handwritten notes which I usually have done for all the courses expect English (mostly done with both diplomas). The bonus assignments quite interesting & good for practicing practical skills although I couldn’t do all due to busy schedule and health issues. I did visit discourse from time to time hoping to find more extra activity but later started helping peers & posting my doubts here. As for ROE 1 didn’t feel it that was difficult but had I not have gotten confused with that timing issue (slowed my paced a little thinking it was an hour) I would have done 2 more questions right. It was good though. The projects helped me put my skills to test which ROE didn’t. I used ChatGPT and it worked out so I gave that ROE marks credit to that GPT LLM. At the very last, I was unsure how to prepare for End term but my peers helped me and will post my digital notes (that’s what I prepared a week ago) after polishing a bit for next term students. .anand sir’s guidance & teachings helped a lot in building these skills and both the TAs were there to help us (can’t thank enough). used ChatGPT fine-tuned for TDS to generate 300+ questions which were really helpful for end term a big thanks to him. End term was a breeze completed within 10-15 minutes with hardly 1-2 questions wrong (mistakes checked with answer key - some courses have released that) Overall, it was a nice experience with some hiccups like issues in GAs & projects but that’s part & parcel of life (nothing is perfect). I hope I will be able to put these skills to good use in real life. Wishing the best for everyone here… Thanks & Regards, Swati Jain
Tagging a few most students for their insights on this

The course was amazing. In my eyes, it is the one course that is truly important because it shows me what life would be like in a Data Science role because more than 60% of the time in any such role is spent in data scraping, data cleaning and EDA. For this, I need to thank Professor .anand and the TAs and . Without their effort, it would not have been possible for me to roll my sleeves up and get into the thick of it, even if it was at a beginner’s level. I hope I can find some roles in the industry which allow me to explore this area a bit more in a real life project. I also feel that given the importance and practical nature of this course, it should be converted to 4 credits with a proper structure and full time instructors to assist the Professor and students.

For me it was more than any 3 credit course being more practical than theoretical with full of experiments on data. I was aware of data analysis at high level before but this course delved me into the new realm of data analytics, drawing insights, trends by help of data visualization. Special thanks to Professor .anand and TAs , . Their extensive support and active help on discourse without which this would have been a mess. Exposing to a real world like project rather than restricting to toy example is what makes this subject. Talking about ROE, It was hard but again LLM was a savior. It did taught one thing how to tackle a problem under pressure of time. End term was everyone’s comfort zone I guess. Thanks to the one who made the Chat GPT TDS TA. It crafted the questions well and due to which everyone was able to give end term. Also special thanks to who conducted a mock for TDS which help to understand difficulty level of questions and gave students a confidence about end term. Regards, Palash H PS. Encourage everyone those who visit this post, feel free to share your experience of TDS.

Thank you for tagging me. I thoroughly enjoyed each and every piece of the course, right from the beginning. As a person coming from a zero programming background, I had to endure the various pain points associated with the course (i am talking about myself) specifically in fetching and scrapping data. I slowly started gaining confidence after watching the videos and TA session recordings multiple times. But that confidence was only short lived as I was completely overrun by the ROE juggernaut. I thought ROE is a real out of the box masterclass . It prepares one to handle real world decision making situations in a better way (utilizing limited resources in a optimal manner). I would say the course was very well designed and structured capturing all the widely used DS tools. It is also heartening to see the course contents being regularly updated to remain in sync with the rapidly changing tools and technologies used in data science. At the end of it, it is only postive takeaways for me from this course. Specifically: Exposure to various tools used in present day DS industry. Kindling interest to delve deeper in to these tools. Giving a birds eye view of the meaningful usage of data and kniiting interesting narratives from it. Professor @ s.anand made the course all the more intersting and lively. Special thanks to him for sharing his rich corporate experience with the students. My TDS experience will not be complete without according special mention to and for their commitment and handholding throughout the term. I feel this course should find a much higher spot than a mere 3 credit course in the whole BS degree programme. Best regards, Rajesh Ramakrishnan

The end term was sort of an anticlimax for a buildup of 12 weeks.
Added term2-2024
It was MUCH easier than expected. I played around with the TA GPT they released and about 80% of the questions today, i had come across before in the GPT.
On top of that, being the only exam I was appearing for, I had to sit for more than an hour doing absolutely nothing.

I finished TDS in about 15 minutes. It was the only exam in the AN session for me too. In the remaining time i also attempted MLF (I had that in FN session) and realised that AN version was much easier, then I completed Python and English 1 paper too (and had 10 minutes remaining). It’s crazy when you realise that the same paper that took me 3 hours to finish when i was in foundation level (Python and English) took me just about 45 minutes now. I dont know if the afternoon sessions exams are actually easy or if i just felt that way. But tbh i dont really know what else they could ask in the end term for TDS since this course is more about knowing the tools than the actual syntax and stuff. Either way i just hope that the project scores are not a disappointment and that they change their minds and do relative grading for the ROE. The experience in this course was great with loads of practical learning. Thanks for that to the team.
